questions.text: On which day does the embryonic fissure close?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The optic pits first appear on day 23 of gestation
  • Evagination of the optic vesicle occurs on day 25, with induction of the lens on day 28.
  • The optic fissure is a natural groove formed during the invagination of the optic vesicle and stalk.
  • It appears on the ventral surface of the developing optic cup, serving as a channel for entry of the hyaloid artery and mesenchymal cells, and later as the exit for retinal neural fibres.
  • Closure of the optic fissure occurs on day 42. During 6 to 7th weeks of gestation, it begins midway between the optic nerve and the iris, and 'zips up' in both anterior and posterior directions.
  • The fissure is located inferiorly on the globe, and the corresponding inferior iris, choroidal, and optic nerve colobomas can be seen with the failure of the fissure to close properly.
  • Lid colobomas are different from these colobomas, as they do not occur from failure of the fetal fissures.

choices.text: Faulty migration of neural crest cells

questions.text: A newborn infant presents with this finding. What developmental anomaly caused this presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient shown has a large chorioretinal coloboma, which is due to incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure.
  • These types of colobomas may involve the optic nerve, choroid, retina, and iris.
  • Faulty migration of neural crest cells results in anterior segment dysgenesis.
  • A differential diagnosis is a morning disc anomaly: a Large excavated disc with abnormal proliferation of glial tissue.

Explanation of other options:

  • Faulty migration of neural crest cells(Option B): Causes structures like Coloboma of eyelid, or anterior segment dysgenesis, but not this classic optic coloboma picture.
  • The exuberant proliferation of glial tissue(Option C) might relate to optic nerve pits or morning‑glory disc anomalies, not coloboma.
  • Abnormal retinal differentiation(Option D): Can cause retinal dysplasia or degeneration, but not the hallmark cleft seen in coloboma.

questions.text: A 2-day-old infant presents with this finding. A developmental anomaly occurred during which stage of ocular embryogenesis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • During the sixth week of gestation, the eyelid folds begin to develop.
  • During the third month, eyelid folds lengthen and fuse. Separation of the upper and lower lids occurs during the fifth month.
  • The patient shown has ankyloblepharon, which is due to incomplete separation of the upper and lower eyelids.

questions.text: This newborn baby's clinical presentation is due to an abnormality during which stage of ocular embryogenesis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The picture shows a patient with Peter's anomaly, which is due to faulty migration of neural crest cells during the sixth week of ocular development.
  • In Peter's anomaly, there is corneal opacity due to dysgenesis of the anterior segment during development. Peter's anomaly affects the iris, corneal endothelium, and Descemet's membrane.
  • Other ocular pathologies include glaucoma, sclerocornea, corectopia, iris hypoplasia, cataract, ICE syndrome, aniridia, iris coloboma, persistent fetal vasculature and microcornea.
  • The anterior chamber and Schlemm's canal develop during months 3 and 4 of gestation.

Peters plus syndrome:

  • This includes short stature, developmental delay, dysmorphic facial features, and cardiac, genitourinary, and central nervous system malformations.

choices.text: Originate from mesenchymal tissue during week 16 of gestation
Grow to the nasal orifice by 32 weeks of gestation
Grow to temporal ora by 34 weeks of gestation
Radiate centrifugally from the optic nerve

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the embryologic development of retinal vessels, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Retinal vessels develop de novo from precursor mesenchymal tissue, beginning during gestational month 4.
  • The vessels radiate outward from the optic nerve, reaching the nasal ora by week 32 and the temporal ora approximately at the 9th month of gestation. Hence, Option C is not true regarding the development of retinal vessels.

choices.text: It is between 8 and 10 mm in length
It is located within the lesser wing of the sphenoid
Sympathetic nerves pass through this canal

questions.text: Which of the following is true of the optic canal?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The optic canal contains the optic nerve, ophthalmic artery, and sympathetic nerves.
  • The superior orbital fissure is separated from the optic canal by the bony optic strut.
  • The canal ranges between 8 and 10 mm in length.
  • It typically measures less than 6.5 mm in diameter at the optic foramen.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a true basement membrane?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Bowman membrane represents a compact collagen layer, a superficial condensed stroma ( a cellular layer ) at the anterior aspect of the corneal stroma.
  • It is not a true basement membrane.

questions.text: Which structure divides the lacrimal gland into two lobes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The lacrimal gland is split into two lobes by the lateral extent of the levator aponeurosis.
  • This aponeurosis splits the gland superficially into two parts: the larger orbital lobe above and the smaller palpebral lobe below.
  • This anatomical division is only partial, with a posterior connection remaining between them.

Explanation of other options:

Orbicularis oculi(Option A): This is a muscle responsible for eyelid closure and tear pumping, not involved in dividing the lacrimal gland.

Tarsus(Option B): The tarsal plates are structural elements of the eyelids and have no role in separating the lacrimal gland lobes.

Whitnall ligament(Option C): Also known as the superior transverse ligament, it provides globe support by suspending the levator muscle but does not bisect the lacrimal gland.

questions.text: Which muscle originates in the orbital apex above the annulus of Zinn?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The superior oblique and levator palpebrae muscles originate in the orbital apex superior to the annulus.
  • All of the recti muscles originate from the annulus of Zinn. (Option B and C)
  • The inferior oblique originates behind the lacrimal fossa. (Option D)
  • The recti muscles insert along the spiral of Tillaux, with the medial rectus being the closest to the limbus (5.5 mm) and the superior rectus being the farthest (7.9 mm).
  • The superior and inferior oblique muscles insert posterior to the equator.
  • The superior oblique inserts on the globe in a long arc, with the anterior fibres near the insertion of the superior rectus.

Key takeaways:

  • The inferior oblique has the shortest tendon length, and the superior oblique has the longest tendon.

questions.text: Which muscle inserts the farthest posterior to the limbus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The recti muscles insert along the spiral of Tillaux, with the medial rectus being the closest to the limbus (5.5 mm) and the superior rectus being the farthest (7.9 mm).
  • The superior and inferior oblique muscles insert posterior to the equator.
  • The superior oblique inserts on the globe in a long arc, with the anterior fibres near the insertion of the superior rectus.

questions.text: The patient seen here presents with the most common childhood primary orbital malignancy, which is due to an abnormal proliferation of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common primary orbital malignancy in children.
  • It arises from undifferentiated pluripotent mesenchymal cells, not extraocular muscle.
  • Histiocytosis X arises from histiocytes, and capillary hemangioma arises from an abnormal proliferation of vascular endothelial cells.

choices.text: The Y suture represents the ends of the lens fibres
The lens nuclei are concentrated near the equator
The lens fibers in the nucleus do not continue to divide throughout life
The anterior Y suture is oriented upright

questions.text: Which statement regarding lens structure is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The lens is formed by the successive division and elongation of lens fibres from embryonic surface ectoderm.
  • The nuclei are found in a lens bow near the equator of the lens.
  • Dividing lens epithelium on the periphery continually adds fibres to the lens throughout life.
  • The ends of the elongated lens fibres meet anteriorly and posteriorly, forming the Y sutures.
  • The anterior suture is upright, whereas the posterior is inverted.

choices.text: They are modified glial cells that provide a structural framework supporting neural elements in the retina
Their nuclei lie in the outer nuclear layer
Their basal processes extend out to form the inner surface of the retina (inner limiting membrane).
The apical or outer cell processes extend beyond the outer nuclear layer, where they are connected to the photoreceptors by a system of terminal bars that comprise the external limiting membrane

questions.text: Which statement regarding Muller cells is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The nuclei of the Müller cells lie in the inner nuclear layer, whereas the nuclei of the photoreceptors lie in the outer nuclear layer.
  • The cell marked with M is the Müller cell, and its nuclei lie in the Inner Nuclear Layer marked as INL.
  • Müller cells are the principal glial (supporting) cells of the retina and are essential for the structural and functional integrity of the retinal tissue.

choices.text: The RPE interdigitates with the apical processes of the rod and cone segments
RPEs are densely adherent to Bruch's membrane
RPEs comprise the inner blood-retinal barrier
RPE cells are taller and contain a greater concentration of pigment in the macula

questions.text: Which statement about the RPE is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • RPE cells comprise the outer blood-retinal barrier; the inner blood–retinal barrier consists of the endothelium lining the retinal blood vessels.
  • (Option A)The RPE interdigitates with the apical processes of the rod and cone photoreceptor outer segments. This relationship is crucial for photoreceptor maintenance and function.
  • (Option B)RPE cells are firmly attached to Bruch's membrane, forming a key structural and functional interface between the retina and the choroid.
  • (Option D)In the macula, RPE cells are taller and more densely pigmented, which helps in reducing light scatter and protecting photoreceptors.

choices.text: It communicates freely with the optic disc capillaries
It is arranged in a segmental pattern that varies with location
The endothelium has a pore size sufficient to allow larger molecules, including proteins, to escape into the extravascular space
It is a major source of nutrition for RPE and outer retinal segments

questions.text: All of the following statements about the choriocapillaris are correct except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The choriocapillaris do not communicate freely with the optic disc capillaries.
  • The choroidal circulation is from the posterior ciliary arteries.
  • The optic disc is mainly supplied by branches of the central retinal artery and the short posterior ciliary arteries, which are distinct from the choriocapillaris.
  • The choriocapillaris primarily supplies the outer retina and RPE, not the optic nerve head.
  • Retinal arterioles are branches of the ophthalmic artery.

Explanation of other options:

Option B: The choriocapillaris has a lobular or segmental architecture, with end-arterial zones supplied by terminal branches of the posterior ciliary arteries. This pattern can vary in different parts of the choroid.

Option C: The choriocapillaris has a fenestrated endothelium with relatively large pores, allowing passage of proteins and other macromolecules. This is essential for nourishing the outer retina and RPE.

Option D: This is a key function of the choriocapillaris. It provides oxygen and nutrients to the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and photoreceptors (which lack a direct retinal blood supply).

choices.text: Axons of the amacrine cells and dendrites of ganglion cells

questions.text: Which one of the following is found in the inner plexiform layer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The inner plexiform layer has axons of the bipolar and amacrine cells and the synapses of the ganglion cells.
  • The nerve fibre layer contains the axons of the ganglion cells. (Option B)
  • The outer plexiform layer has connections between the photoreceptors, horizontal cells, and bipolar cells. (Option C)
  • The footplates of the Müller cells form the internal limiting membrane(Option D)

questions.text: How many degrees is the fovea displaced from the optic nerve?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fovea displaced from the optic nerve by 15°.
  • This information is helpful when locating the blind spot in visual fields.
  • The diameter of the retinal vein as it crosses the edge of the optic nerve head is 120 μm.

questions.text: What is the diameter of the retinal vein as it crosses the edge of the optic nerve head?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diameter of the retinal vein as it crosses the edge of the optic nerve head is 120 μm

questions.text: Each rectus muscle is supplied by two to three anterior ciliary arteries, except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Each of the four rectus muscles of the eye typically gives rise to 2 anterior ciliary arteries, which contribute to the major arterial circle of the iris and supply the anterior segment of the eye.
  • However, the lateral rectus is the exception - it is usually supplied by only one anterior ciliary artery.
  • Anterior ciliary arteries are crucial in anterior segment perfusion.
  • Damage during strabismus surgery (especially if multiple muscles are involved) can lead to anterior segment ischemia.

choices.text: The volume of the orbit is 30 ml
The maximum width is 1 cm behind the anterior orbital margin
The depth of the orbit averages 50 mm from the orbital entrance to the apex
The medial walls are parallel and border the nasal cavity, ethmoid air cells, and sphenoid sinus posteriorly

questions.text: Which one of the following statements describing the adult orbit is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The depth of the orbit varies from 40 to 45 mm from the orbital entrance to the orbital apex.
  • The distance to the apex becomes important in the dissection or excision of a tumour in the posterior orbit or the repair of an extensive blowout fracture.

choices.text: The Lacrimal sac fossa is bordered by the lacrimal and maxillary bones
Nasolacrimal sac, duct, and canaliculi are lined by stratified squamous epithelium
Nasolacrimal duct measures 12 to 15 mm in adults
Nasolacrimal duct opens into the inferior meatus

questions.text: Which one of the following statements about the nasolacrimal system is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The nasolacrimal system is lined with pseudostratified columnar epithelium, similar to that found in the upper respiratory system. Hence, Option D is false about the nasolacrimal system.
  • The lacrimal sac fossa is bordered by the anterior lacrimal crest of the maxillary bone and the posterior lacrimal crest of the lacrimal bone.
  • In adults, the canaliculi are 10 mm long (8 mm horizontal, 2 mm vertical), the nasolacrimal sac is 10 mm, and the duct is 12 to 15 mm in length.
  • The lacrimal duct extends into the inferior meatus 3 to 5 mm before opening at the membranous valve of Hasner.

F = frontal sinus, IT = inferior turbinate, MT = middle turbinate, S = sphenoid sinus, ST = superior turbinate.

choices.text: The mucocutaneous junction of the eyelid margin
The location of the meibomian gland orifices

questions.text: The 'Grayline' of the eyelid is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The grey line corresponds to the lid's orbicularis muscle layer, the muscle of Riolan.
  • The location of the meibomian gland orifices is at the posterior part of the lid margin; the anterior part of the lid margin has the eyelash.
  • A shallow groove is seen between the anterior and posterior lamellae of the eyelid.
  • It lies just anterior to the meibomian gland orifices and is used as a surgical landmark for eyelid margin procedures.

questions.text: A full-thickness stab incision located 11 mm superior to the eyelid margin over the pupil in the Caucasian upper eyelid would be close to each of the following structures except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Glands of Moll's are not involved because they are located close to the eyelid margin.
  • A full-thickness incision in the upper eyelid 11 mm superior to the eyelid margin, would involve the skin, orbicularis, orbital fat, and levator aponeurosis.
  • The incision may also pass through the peripheral arterial arcade, the superior tarsal muscle, and the conjunctiva.
  • The accessory glands of Wolfring are located along the orbital margin of each tarsus.
  • The accessory lacrimal glands of Krause are located in the fornices, and most reside in the lateral part of the upper fornix.

questions.text: An abnormality in which eyelid structure can cause this clinical presentation.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient shown in this figure has epiblepharon,
  • Epiblepharon is a condition in which the eyelid pretarsal muscle and skin ride above the eyelid margin to form a horizontal fold of tissue that causes the cilia to assume a vertical position.
  • Epiblepharon is more common in Asian infants.
  • Lash-corneal touch and secondary keratitis can occur.
  • It should be differentiated from ectropion and entropion, which present with outward and inward rotation of the lid margin, respectively.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male shown here is referred for evaluation of congenital ptosis. Which of the following abnormal examination findings would you expect to see?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A patient with congenital ptosis will present with minimal to absent levator function.
  • Poor or reduced levator function (typically <4 mm of eyelid excursion)
  • A low or absent upper eyelid crease (due to poor levator aponeurosis insertion)
  • Possible chin-up head posture (to compensate for visual axis obstruction)

Explanation of other options:

  • Reduced frontalis function(Option B): Not typical. Frontalis overaction is often seen as a compensatory mechanism in congenital ptosis.
  • Trigemino-oculomotor synkinesis(Option C): This refers to Marcus Gunn jaw-winking syndrome, a specific variant of congenital ptosis, but not universally present in all cases. It is not expected in routine congenital ptosis.
  • Abnormally high upper eyelid crease(Option D): The opposite is true. Congenital ptosis usually presents with a low or absent crease due to poor levator function.

questions.text: What is the anteroposterior diameter of an adult eyeball?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dimensions of an adult eyeball:

  • Anteroposterior diameter: 24 mm
  • Horizontal diameter: 23.5 mm
  • Vertical diameter: 23 mm
  • Circumference: 75 mm
  • Volume: 6.5 ml
  • Weight: 7 g.
  • The depth of the orbit varies from 40 to 45 mm from the orbital entrance to the orbital apex.

questions.text: What is the volume of an adult eyeball?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dimensions of an adult eyeball

  • Anteroposterior diameter: 24 mm
  • Horizontal diameter 23.5 mm
  • Vertical diameter: 23 mm
  • Circumference: 75 mm
  • Volume: 6.5 ml
  • Weight 7 g

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not a part of the posterior segment of the eye?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The posterior segment of the eye includes the structures posterior to the lens :

  • Vitreous humour (a gel-like structure which fills the space behind the lens)
  • Retina
  • Choroid
  • Optic disc.

The Anterior segment includes:

  • Cornea
  • Anterior chamber
  • Posterior chamber
  • Iris
  • Ciliary body
  • Crystalline lens

questions.text: Identify the structure labelled as 4.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • 1- orbital rim
  • 2- vitreous
  • 3- eyelids
  • 4- optic nerve
  • 5- connective, adipose and muscular tissues
  • 6- sclera
  • 7- cornea
  • 8- zonules
  • 9- anterior chamber
  • 10- lens

questions.text: What is the motor nerve supply of the orbicularis oculi muscles of the eyelids?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Motor nerves - 3rd, 4th and 6th cranial nerves supply the extraocular muscles, and 7th cranial nerve branches supply the orbicularis oculi muscle of the eyelids.

Nerve supply of the eye:

Sensory Innervation:

  • Optic nerve (CN II):
    • Carries visual sensory input from the retina to the brain.
  • Ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V1):
    • Provides general sensory innervation to:
      • Cornea (via the nasociliary nerve)
      • Sclera
      • Conjunctiva
      • Eyelids
      • Lacrimal gland (afferent limb of reflex)
    • Branches involved: Lacrimal, Frontal, and Nasociliary nerves

Motor Innervation (Somatic):

  • Oculomotor nerve (CN III):
    • Innervates 4 extraocular muscles:
      • Superior rectus
      • Inferior rectus
      • Medial rectus
      • Inferior oblique
    • Also supplies the levator palpebrae superioris (elevates the upper eyelid)
  • Trochlear nerve (CN IV):
    • Innervates the superior oblique muscle
  • Abducens nerve (CN VI):
    • Innervates the lateral rectus muscle

Autonomic Innervation:

Parasympathetic (via CN III):

  • Preganglionic fibres travel in the oculomotor nerve to the ciliary ganglion
  • Postganglionic fibres (short ciliary nerves) innervate:
    • Sphincter pupillae (pupil constriction)
    • Ciliary muscle (accommodation)

Sympathetic:

  • Originates from the superior cervical ganglion
  • Postganglionic fibres travel via long ciliary nerves (from the nasociliary nerve)
  • Targets:
    • Dilator pupillae (pupil dilation)
    • Superior tarsal (Müller's) muscle (assists eyelid elevation)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the ophthalmic artery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Ophthalmic artery, a branch of the internal carotid artery, constitutes the main source of blood supply for the eyeball and other orbital structures.

Branches of the ophthalmic artery include:

Ocular group:

  • Central retinal artery
  • Long posterior ciliary arteries
  • Short posterior ciliary arteries
  • Muscular branches -Anterior ciliary arteries

Orbital Group:

  • Lacrimal artery - Lateral palpebral artery
  • Recurrent meningeal artery
  • Supraorbita1 artery
  • Medial palpebral artery
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery
  • Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Dorsal nasal artery (terminal branch)
  • Supratrochlear artery (terminal branch)

choices.text: It supplies preganglionic fibres through the 3rd cranial nerve to the ciliary ganglion
Postganglionic nerve fibres from the ciliary ganglion supply the sphincter pupillae muscle
Postganglionic fibres from the accessory ganglion supply the ciliary muscle
It supplies preganglionic fibres through the 5th cranial nerve to the accessory ciliary ganglion

questions.text: Which statement is not true for the Edinger-Westphal nucleus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Edinger-Westphal nucleus, located in the midbrain, sends:

  • Preganglionic fibres through the third cranial nerve to the ciliary ganglion and accessory ganglion.
  • Postganglionic nerve fibres from the ciliary ganglion travel along the short ciliary nerves to supply the sphincter pupillae muscle, and postganglionic fibres from the accessory ganglion supply the ciliary muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the nasociliary nerve?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lacrimal nerve, the frontal nerve and the nasociliary nerve are the branches of the ophthalmic nerve.

The frontal nerve divides into two branches :

  • Supratrochlear nerve
  • Supraorbital nerve

The nasociliary nerve divides into:

  • Long ciliary nerves
  • Communicating branches to the ciliary ganglion
  • Posterior ethmoidal nerve
  • Anterior ethmoidal nerve
  • Infra-trochlear nerve

choices.text: It derives nourishment from the aqueous humour
Dua's layer lies between Bowman's membrane and stroma

questions.text: Which statement about the cornea is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The cornea is the transparent front part of the eye, which resembles a "watch glass" and consists of different layers and regions:
    • Epithelium
    • Bowman's membrane
    • Stroma (substantia propria)
    • Dua's layer (pre-Descemet's layer)
    • Descemet's membrane
    • Endothelium
  • The cornea is avascular with no blood vessels, with the exception of minute arcades extending about 1 mm into the cornea at the limbus.
  • It is dependent for its nourishment upon diffusion of tissue fluid from the vessels at its periphery and the aqueous humour.
  • The cornea is very richly supplied with unmyelinated nerve fibres derived from the trigeminal nerve.

questions.text: A major arterial circle is present at
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The major arterial circle of the iris is formed mainly by anastomoses of the long posterior ciliary arteries and anterior ciliary arteries.
  • It is located in the ciliary body, near the root of the iris, which is the base where the iris joins the ciliary body.

Explanation of other Options:

  • Pupillary border of iris(Option B): This is where the minor arterial circle is found.
  • Near optic disc (Option C): This region is related to the central retinal artery, not the major arterial circle.
  • Near Ora Serrata(Option D): This is the junction between the retina and ciliary body, not where the major arterial circle is located.

questions.text: Name this congenital anomaly
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A rare congenital anomaly where the eyelids fail to form, and skin covers the globe (or where the eye would be). The eye may be absent, rudimentary, or malformed beneath the skin.

Key Features:

  • Absence of palpebral fissure (no visible eyelids)
  • Skin extends continuously from the forehead to the cheek, covering the area where the eye should be
  • The globe is often malformed or underdeveloped (can be associated with microphthalmos or anophthalmos)
  • Often bilateral, but can be unilateral.
  • Associated with Fraser syndrome (which includes other anomalies like syndactyly, genital malformations, and renal defects).

Explanation of other options:

Anophthalmos(Option A): Complete absence of the eye (globe).

Microphthalmos(Option C): Abnormally small but still present eye.

Nanophthalmos(Option D): Eye is small but structurally normal; a subtype of microphthalmos with high risk for angle-closure glaucoma.
